message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Once the patient is infected with a nephritogenic strain of group A streptococcus, the development of PSGN cannot be prevented with antibiotics. Antibiotics are only used to treat the initial strep throat infection and to prevent complications like rheumatic fever, but they do not prevent the development of PSGN.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. While antibiotics can be used to treat strep throat and prevent complications such as rheumatic fever, they cannot prevent the development of PSGN once a patient is infected with a nephritogenic strain of group A streptococcus. Therefore, option B is the correct answer. There is no evidence to suggest that antibiotic therapy can prevent the development of PSGN or decrease its severity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Antibiotics cannot prevent the development of PSGN once a patient is infected with a nephritogenic strain of group A streptococcus. However, antibiotics can help in treating strep throat and preventing other complications like rheumatic fever. Antibiotic therapy is not indicated for immunosuppressed patients, and there is currently no evidence that it decreases the severity of PSGN.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Antibiotic therapy does not prevent the development of PSGN once a patient is infected with a nephritogenic strain of group A streptococcus. Antibiotics are only recommended for the treatment of strep throat to prevent the development of complications such as rheumatic fever. Once PSGN has developed, antibiotics will not prevent its progression.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Antibiotic therapy for strep throat can prevent the development of acute rheumatic fever, but it cannot prevent the development of PSGN. Once a patient is infected with a nephritogenic strain of group A streptococcus, the development of PSGN cannot be prevented.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. PSGN is a rare complication of strep throat caused by certain nephritogenic strains of group A streptococcus. Antibiotics are not recommended to prevent PSGN, as the disease is a result of an immune response to the infection and not the infection itself. Therefore, the most appropriate response is (B) Once a patient is infected with a nephritogenic strain of group A streptococcus, the development of PSGN cannot be prevented.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Antibiotics can prevent the development of acute rheumatic fever, but current evidence shows that they do not prevent the development of PSGN. Once a patient is infected with a nephritogenic strain of group A streptococcus, the development of PSGN cannot be prevented.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Antibiotic therapy is not indicated for the treatment of strep throat in most cases and is not indicated for the prevention of PSGN. Once a patient is infected with a nephritogenic strain of group A streptococcus, the development of PSGN cannot be prevented. Antibiotic therapy may decrease the duration of the strep infection but will not prevent the development of PSGN.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Once a patient is infected with a nephritogenic strain of group A streptococcus, the development of PSGN cannot be prevented by antibiotics. Antibiotics are used to treat strep throat to prevent complications such as rheumatic fever, which can also lead to glomerulonephritis. The best course of action for this patient is to manage his symptoms and monitor his kidney function.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. PSGN is caused by an immune response to a specific strain of group A streptococcus and antibiotics do not prevent the development of PSGN once a patient is infected with a nephritogenic strain. Antibiotics may be used to treat the initial streptococcal infection, but they do not prevent PSGN. Option D is also incorrect as there is no evidence that antibiotics decrease the severity of PSGN.
